instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1369: What is A1369? A1369 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Air from years Late 2010, Mid 2011 with EMC 2392, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-2838, 820-3023..
definitions.820-00426: What is 820-00426? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.820-3787: What is 820-3787? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.820-3662: What is 820-3662? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1369</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00426</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - 0.2A after liquid damage. Short on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Hey Guys

Came across this with liquid damage around Phase 1/2 chips <CHIP>U7320</CHIP> and <CHIP>U7330</CHIP>. I don't have this schematic, but <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> seems to be as close as I can get.
Seems like there is short on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> ad I can feel quarter of <CHIP>U7320</CHIP> heating up.
Removed F7140/F7141 to isolate the short and seems like its on the CPU side.

Lifted L7320 and short is gone. So I was wondering have you guys seen these phase chips failing? Could I have dead CPU, especially with the liquid around this area?

Also, my hot air recently failed and I replaced it with doggy AOUYE 968 I had laying around. I am not sure if the hot air is weak or the area is shorting all to ground, but I cannot even get the solders to melt on this chip. Whole board gets hot but the bloody chip is not coming out.
Have you experienced anything like this before? Planing to order this[URL='https://www.unionrepair.com/quick-881d-1300w-hot-air-desoldering-rework-station.html'] quick 881 1,3KW from unionrepair[/URL]. Is it still best for my buck?

Thanks

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1369</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00426</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - 0.2A after liquid damage. Short on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Most likely dead CPU now.
If short on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> disappeared when lifted L7320, then <CHIP>U7320</CHIP> is the culprit.
Lift L7310/30 too and checl exact ohm value to ground at <RESISTOR>R7320</RESISTOR>; compare with working board, if possible.

"I cannot even get the solders to melt on this chip "
Matbe don't even need to remove it, if CPU is dead.

But you can practice, just in case.
First, remove CPU heatsink.
Next, preheat logic board on large area, especially opposite side of <CHIP>U7320</CHIP>; a small preheater, Mlink 853A helps a lot.
I recommend to practice on scrap boards first.
Once chip is removed, apply only bit of leaded solder on central pad.
Is also good to pass with lead on top of other pads...

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1369</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00426</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - 0.2A after liquid damage. Short on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Thanks for your reply.

Lifted the mentioned coils and all three <RESISTOR>R7310</RESISTOR>/20/30 are giving 0.16ohm to ground. My Fluke's precision is 0.10ohm

I don't have the same board however, I have <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> (without dedicated GPU) which turns on but have picture issues (overheated so much that heatsink support legs got desoldered from the board, not sure if CPU reflow can save it )

It seems to be having the same 3 phases and the same chips.
I lift up the coils on <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> and measured at <RESISTOR>R7310</RESISTOR>/20/30 and got 16-17ohm. Would that mean dead CPU on <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00426</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>?

Thanks for the tips, much appreciated.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1369</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00426</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - 0.2A after liquid damage. Short on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
No CPU can have less than 1 ohm!!!
So your board is trash now.
You can practice on it...
